data.title: 7 Fascinating Facts About Victor Hugo's 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame'
data.meta_description: You likely know of Quasimodo, of Esmeralda, maybe you know Dom Claude Frollo or even Captain Phoebus â¦ but here are some facts about The Hunchback of Notre Dame you might not know.
data.text:
If youâre not a reader, the last time (and possibly the first time) you thought about the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris may have been when it went up in flames three years ago. Fortunately, 400 Parisian firefighters were able to extinguish the flames, and restoration has been in progress since then. Tourists are still not allowed inside, but the cathedral is easy to marvel at from its courtyard.

If you are a reader, though, youâre undoubtedly familiar with Victor Hugoâs 1831 novel, The Hunchback of Notre Dame, a work of historical fiction set in the Gothic Era of Paris. (Its opening line throws us back âthree hundred and forty-eight years, six months, and nineteen daysâ to January 6, 1482; for some historical perspective, the story takes place only 51 years after Joan of Arc was burned at the stake.) You likely know of Quasimodo, of Esmeralda, maybe you know Dom Claude Frollo or even Captain Phoebus â¦ but here are some facts about Hunchback you might not know.

1. Victor Hugo was super late submitting his manuscript to his publisher.

As Graham Robb writes in his biography of Hugo, the authorâs initial due date for the manuscript was April 15, 1829âbut he missed it. A year soon passed, during which a new deadline was negotiated with Hugoâs publisher (and not by Hugo himself, but by an intermediary): December 1, 1830. âThis time,â Robb writes, âfor every week the novel was late, Hugo would forfeit 1000 francs.â

But the author missed that deadline as wellâthe July Revolution had erupted, so Hugo told his publisher that he had lost important notes and got a two-month extension. Hugo then underwent âextreme self-disciplineâ to avoid the penalty, Robb writes, buying âa grey woollen body-stocking, a new bottle of ink, lock[ing] his clothes in the wardrobe and âenter[ing] his novel like a prison.ââ According to author John Sturrock, Hugo actually started seriously writing on September 1 and finished January 14 or 15, âa book of almost 200,000 words written in four and a half months.â

2. In French, the title is Notre-Dame de Paris.

In her introduction to the 2002 edition of The Hunchback of Notre Dame, author Elizabeth McCracken writes that Hugo, who called his book Notre-Dame de Paris, hated the title that accompanied the English translation of his novel, which she notes ânarrows the book down to one character and one building. In fact, this is a book full of heroes and monsters, saints and gargoyles, and saints-turned-gargoyles.â According to Britannica, Hugoâwho believed that Franceâs architecture was a key part of its heritageâintended for the book to be âa story of the cathedral itselfâ as well as âa plea for the preservation of the cityâs historic Gothic architecture (and thus its heritage).â

Why the title was changed for Frederic Shoberlâs popular 1833 English translation is unclear, but it may have been influenced by the publisher thinking that British audiences cared more about the story and characters than the building.

3. Disneyâs animated adaptation tweaked much about Hugoâs novelâwhich has led to a number of misconceptions.

Hugoâs novel has inspired countless adaptations and re-imaginings, including an opera by Louise Bertin in 1836, for which Hugo himself wrote the libretto; a 1923 silent film starring Lon Chaney; and, of course, the infamous 1996 animated film by Disney, which ended up perpetuating many misconceptions about Notre-Dame.

In Hugoâs novel, Clopin Trouillefou isnât the host of the Feast of Fools, as in the Disney cartoon, but the King of the Cour des Miraclesâand that Cour des Miracles bore very little resemblance to Disneyâs version (though one thing Disney did get right is that the name is tongue-in-cheek).

According to Atlas Obscura, during the reign of Louis XIVâover 100 years after the events of Hunchbackâthe number of people experiencing homelessness and poverty boomed, and begging became the main means of survival for many. A key strategy for eliciting sympathy (and money) from those more fortunate was to pretend to have a physical disability. When they returned to the slum at night, they no longer needed to put on the act and were âmiraculously âcuredâ of these ailments.â

While the historicity of the story is debated, this supposedly led the slum to be referred to as the Court of Miraclesâand it so inspired Hugoâs writing that it was also featured in another of his most famous novels, Les Miserables.

The character of Clopin in the cartoon also doesnât have much in common with the Clopin of Hugoâs novel, who is the leader of a street gang of tramps who must undertake dangerous initiation rituals. The gangs went unchecked because Paris had no police force in the late 1400sâjust its Army.

And remember the scene where Phoebus and Quasimodo go through the catacombs to get to the Court of Miracles? It didnât happen in the novel, and with good reason: The Catacombs of Paris were not created until the late 1700s, when the overcrowded Saints-Innocents cemetery caused a public health concern, and corpses were disinterred to Parisâs collapsing quarries.Â

The end of the novel was also changed for the Disney adaptation to make it much less grim. In Hugoâs novel, Esmeralda is convicted of a murder (along with crimes of âsorcery, magic, and lasciviousnessâ) that she did not commit, and rather than riding off into the sunset with her handsome soldier, sheâs executed by hanging. Grief-stricken, Quasimodo goes to Esmeraldaâs grave, where he, too, dies. No one notices his death for years.

4. Quasimodo has a condition called kyphosis.

Kyphosis is when thereâs a curvature in the spine; people who live with it in the real world can also experience breathing and digestive problems as well as limited physical functions. In Hugoâs novel, however, Quasimodo has superhuman strength as a result of his postureâthough this doesnât stop society from disowning him based on his appearance. Heâs further detached from society by deafness that occurs as a result of years ringing Notre Dameâs bells.

5. Esmeraldaâs fate illustrates Hugoâs opinion of the death penalty.

The hanging of innocent Esmeralda probably makes his stance clear, but it bears mentioning that Hugo did not support the death penaltyâin fact, he actively spoke out against it, both before and after Hunchback.

In 1829, he published The Last Day of a Condemned Man, a novel written from the perspective of a man who was shortly set to die. (In an introduction to the 1832 edition, he explicitly spelled out that his goal was to abolish the death penalty.) After being elected to the legislature in 1848, Hugo gave a speech saying, âLook, examine, reflect â¦ You hold capital punishment up as an example. Why? Because of what it teaches. And just what is it that you wish to teach by means of this example? That thou shalt not kill. And how do you teach that thou shalt not kill? By killing.â

Political stances like these (as well as things like calling Emperor Napoleon III a traitor for abolishing the democratic system of government in France) led to Hugo being exiled from France in the early 1850s. Napoleon III granted all exiles amnesty in 1859, but Hugo said, âFaithful to the undertaking I have given my conscience, I shall share the exile of freedom to the end. When freedom returns, so shall I.â

Hugo didnât return to France until after the fall of the Second Empire in the early 1870s. At that point, he was elected to the National Assembly (then resigned after just a month) and, later, the Senate. Now, Hugo is memorialized in the Pantheon among Franceâs other national heroes.Â

6. Hugo wrote at a standing desk.

One of Hugoâs more forward-thinking habits was writing on a standing desk; according to Smithsonian, the author âwould find various pieces of furniture he liked and would work with carpenters to combine them into single pieces. The results were stylistically eclectic and, as evidenced by his stand-up writers desk, which seems to be made from a standard desk and a coffee table, seemed to be uniquely suited to accommodate his own habits and eccentricities.â You can see his standing desk at Hugoâs Place des Vosges apartment, now a museum.

7. The book saved Notre Dame Cathedral.
